Post.title: Angular 5 MEAN app
Post.subtitle: Setting up MEAN app with angular cli and express-generator
Post.author: Andrei Sbitnev
Post.content:
Quick Start

To build the project you need the angular cli and express-generator installed on your operating system.

You will also need a mongoDb either installed on your system, or running inside a Docker container. Since we`ll be Dockerizing the project in the next tutorial, we will use the container version.

To run any docker container, Docker must first be installed on your system.

Tip: Use a CE version

To create and run a mongoDb container, just run the

TIP: -d - means run detached, -p - port forwarding, mongodb - is the name of your container. You can then start and stop the container by running sudo docker container start mongodb or sudo docker container stop mongodb.

Setting up the project

Create a new directory smart-home and cd into it.

Start a new Angular 5 project using angular cli

Start a new express project using express-generator

Configuring backend

Open up the project in your favorite text editor and open the ~/smart-home/be/app.js file

We will be using the be app only as a REST api, so we don`t need views or view engine. Remove the following lines from the file.

We also won`t be serving any static files or a favicon with the be app, so remove the following lines from the ~/be/app.js file

And the public folder

We also won`t be needing the index route, so let`s remove it from the project. Remove the following lines from the from the ~/be/app.js file.

And the index.js file from the ~/be/routes directory

We can also remove the unnecessary dependencies from the ~/be/package.json file.

Tip: Don`t forget to remove the comma from the end of the package.json file.

Now let`s install all the dependencies. Just cd into the ~/smart-home/be folder and run

Although it is possible to communicate with mongoDb without any additional packages, we will be using the Mongoose.js library for that purpose. So let`s add it to the dependencies. Just cd into the ~/smart-home/be folder and run

And connect to the database.

Since our frontend and backend will be running as separate services on different ports, or maybe even on different servers, we need to set appropriate headers, to allow frontend send requests to the backend.

The final ~/be/app.js file should look like this

Simple server for the frontend

In this project build we are using angular cli, which is a simple and powerful tool for building and running angular applications in development. It comes with a preconfigured testing environment and a dev server, but it is not a good idea to use the dev server in production. Lets next setup a simple production server for angular.

Go to ~/smart-home/fe and add a new file server.js

In the code above we add a static directory, which will hold all of our static files and most importantly the bundle.js file. By default angular cli will create a bundle in the dist folder of your project.

We then setup a single endpoint with a wildcard *, which will always get called, no matter what is specified in the url.

This is important, because all the routing and error handling in an angular app should be done on the frontend.

Finally we add a server to listen on port 4200, which is the same port used to serve the application by angular dev server.

Lets now modify the fe package.json file to use the newly created server. Go to ~/smart-home/fe and modify the scripts object in the package.json file.

To run the angular dev server use npm run dev. To run the app in production, first build it npm run build, and then run it npm start.

Testing the MEAN app components working together.

The MEAN app is basically setup by now, but it would be great to test if angular, express and mongoDb are correctly set up and can communicate with each other.

For this purpose we will add a test component to our angular app, which will have a form with a single input and a button. The form will be sent to the backend, and then saved to mongoDb in the test database. We will also fetch all the values from the test database and display them below the form as a list.

We won`t be going into further detail about angular or express at this point, because it`s not the purpose of this tutorial. All the steps will be shown and described in upcoming tutorials, when we`ll be actually building the app.

Run the ng generate component test to add a new component to angular app. Below are listed all the files, that need to be added or changed for the test app to run correctly, and what they should contain.

~/smart-home/fe/src/app/app.component.html

~/smart-home/fe/src/app/test/test.component.html

~/smart-home/fe/src/app/test/test.component.ts

~/smart-home/fe/src/app/app.module.ts

Add a new directory models in ~/smart-home/be, which will hold the mongoose.js models, and add a test model.

~/smart-home/be/models/test.js

Add a new routes file test.js

~/smart-home/be/routes/test.js

~/smart-home/be/app.js

Starting the application

To test the application, first start the mongodb server

Tip: If it is set up in the Docker container, as described above, just run sudo docker container start mongodb

Start the backend server, by navigating inside the ~/smarthouse/be and running npm start

Open up another terminal and start an angular app, by navigating inside the ~/smarthouse/fe and running npm run dev

Now open the browser and go to http://localhost:4200, you should see a white page with one input field and a disabled submit button. Enter something in the input field and submit it to the server. The submitted text should appear below the form as a line in a list. You can now refresh the page, and the list should remain unchanged.
